problem.markdown: Imagine you are a course leader on a new course. It hasn’t yet gone live but there is a lot of interest already in your course, which is being run for both on campus students and open to the public. You’re really excited about your students being part of a bigger community, although you want to set up a discussion area just for students so they can talk about additional assignments. >>Could cohorts be helpful, and if so how should they be set up?<< (!) Yes. Automatic allocation of ~4-5 cohorts would give flexibility. (X) Yes. A manual allocation cohort to restrict access to specific units about additional assignments, with a discussion component, provides a good solution. ( ) Yes. Run the course as an A-B experiment (aka "Content Experiment" or "split-test") to make two groups. (@) No. You want students to integrate but cohorts will shut them off from seeing posts from others on the course. [explanation] We're not saying it's the only solution, but it's definitely more controllable than A/B testing or automatic allocation. [explanation]
